title: Understanding Protons
text: Recall what defines an element in the periodic table. What does having a specific number of protons do for an element?

title: Element Identity
text: If an element has a different number of protons, does it remain the same element? Think about how elements are organized in the periodic table.

title: Proton Count
text: Can two atoms of different elements share the same proton count? Why or why not?

title: Clarify what isotopes are
text: Remember, isotopes are variations of elements with the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons. What does this imply about 15N and 16O?

title: Consider the number of neutrons
text: List the number of neutrons for each isotope of nitrogen and oxygen. Is there a neutron count that appears in both lists?

title: Check each isotope individually
text: Look at each isotope's neutron number independently. For instance, how many neutrons does 15N have? How many does 16O have?

title: Understanding Ionic Charges
text: When ions are formed, electrons are either gained or lost. Consider how the charge affects the electron count in nitrogen and oxygen ions.

title: Counting Electrons in Ions
text: Calculate the total number of electrons for N and O when they form different ions, such as N³⁻ and O²⁻. Does the electron count become the same?

title: Understanding Charges
text: Think about the conditions under which atoms would have no overall charge. What does it mean for an atom to be neutral?
